awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Effective Preference Reasoning over Combinatorial Domains: Principles, Problems, Algorithms, and Implementations
awd_abstract_narration:
Preferences are fundamental attributes of human reasoning and decision making. They appear whenever a choice between alternatives is to be made. Understanding and automating preference reasoning is a major problem of artificial intelligence, especially important for the design of autonomous intelligent decision support systems. If there are few alternatives, preferences between them can be represented explicitly and preference reasoning is typically easy. However, in practice the number of alternatives facing the decision maker can be daunting in many cases.  In such cases, modeling and representing preferences of the decision maker, and automating preference reasoning based on the model are challenging. To respond to the challenge, the project will study principles and properties of preference aggregation and optimization over large domains of alternatives, and algorithms to support preference reasoning tasks; will develop methods for preference learning and approximation in support of building preference models; and will implement software for effective preference modeling and reasoning. Areas such as knowledge representation, computational social choice, and constraint solving embodied by answer-set programming and satisfiability testing will inform these studies. The project will result in a theoretical and algorithmic framework for preference reasoning over combinatorial domains, in software tools for effective preference reasoning, and in methods to integrate them into artificial intelligence decision support systems that are becoming pervasive in industrial, scientific and governmental applications. 

The project will assume that the space of alternatives is modeled by a combinatorial domain, where alternatives are represented in terms of values of attributes relevant to decision making. While combinatorial domains are exponentially large in the number of attributes, the sets of values of individual attributes are typically small. This opens a possibility of expressing preferences over elements in a combinatorial domain in terms of preferences on attribute values and relations between the attributes. This is the setting for the project, with preference trees, CP-nets and answer set optimization programs as formal representations of preferences over combinatorial domains. The project will focus on preference aggregation and preference optimization. Finding optimal and near-optimal alternatives, finding collections of optimal or near-optimal alternatives that are in some sense diverse (or similar), and aggregating preferences that are only partially known are some examples of specific problems we will consider. As building manually preference models over large domains is infeasible, the project will study methods to learn preference models (for instance, preference trees), and develop methods for model approximation (different models have varying computational properties, and close approximations of ``hard'' models with ``easy'' ones may prove effective for reasoning with the former).  Finally, the project will develop a software suite for several key preference reasoning tasks. The implementation will exploit advances in answer-set programming and satisfiability. The resulting software will be systematically evaluated on benchmarks coming from or motivated by practical applications.

por.por_cntn:
Preferences are fundamental attributes of human reasoning and decision making. They appear whenever a choice between alternatives (called outcomes in this document) is to be made. Buying a car we consider safety, economy, convenience, and appearance. Planning a vacation we consider our preferences for the location, time of year, mode of transportation, attractions, and cost. This project advanced our understanding of preference representation, and resulted in algorithms for reasoning with preferences and in software tools to support preference reasoning tasks. It did so by exhibiting and exploiting cross-fertilizing connections between preference reasoning, social choice theory, knowledge representation and, answer set programming. The most significant outcomes of the project are:


(1) A novel approach to preference aggregation. Whenever decisions are to be made among several options that different stakeholders may value differently, some form of preference aggregation (similar to a voting rule in elections) is needed. The project proposed to perform preference aggregation by learning a preference model from partial information about individual preferences, and developed techniques, algorithms and software supporting this way of building consensus.

(2) One of the fundamental preference reasoning tasks is selecting a better (preferred) option between the two available ones (formally, dominance testing). This task is often computationally hard because of the way agent's preferences are represented. This project proposed to address the problem by trading accuracy for performance and demonstrated its feasibility for the case when agent's preferences are represented as conditional preference networks (CP-nets) and approximations are constructed by means of conditional lexicographic preference models. Solving the dominance testing problem for the former is hard. But it is easy for the latter. CP-nets form one of the most broadly considered ways to model agent's preferences. This project proved that one can use the information about agent's preferences given as a CP-net for fast approximate preference reasoning. 

(3) An important case of preference aggregation occurs in fair division problems studied by social choice. Given a set of goods to be allocated among several agents, with each agent having her own utility function on the goods, the task is to find an allocation that is fair, for some agreed upon form of fairness. Maximin share criterion is one of the more commonly studied. Under this criterion, the goal is to allocate to each agent a bundle of goods valued at least at what that this agent would be guaranteed to obtain if she were to propose a partition, agents were selecting bundles in turn, and she was the last one to choose. The project resulted in first suites of algorithms and software for computing maximin share allocations in a general case, when only some bundles are considered legitimate. The software is built on top of answer set programming, demonstrating the power of this latter technology in addressing fair division problems.

The latter outcome is especially meaningful due to its cross-area flavor as it connects preference reasoning, answer set programming and social choice.

An important objective of the project was to contribute to the human capital. The project served as a training ground for several students, two of them women and two of them undergraduates. Two of these students already graduated, one will graduate in December 2020 and one will graduate in 2021.
